Abridged version of a piece I am working on called

"Rethinking Ethereum Wallets"

Ethereum's account and wallet model for end users has barely evolved since its early days. The assumption that "a user account == a single address" (usually an Externally Owned Account, or EOA) is the _original sin_ of Ethereum wallet UX. This outdated paradigm is holding back innovation and making Ethereum needlessly complex, cumbersome, and privacy-leaking for users.

When you open MetaMask, Rabby, Rainbow, or any other browser wallet, you see a dropdown list of EOAs--single-address accounts that you must manually switch between. Each address is treated as an isolated entity/identity/namespace, and is utilized as a separate signer and transaction originator. The result is that users are forced to manage their assets and interactions at the _individual address level_, rather than at a more _abstract account level_.

Even more modern smart contract wallets (such as Safe) still model a user "account" as a single address. These wallets give us _account abstraction_ in the form of flexible authorization policies on a single user account and _gas abstraction_ since any EOA can relay authorized transactions and pay gas on behalf of the user account, but make no direct progress on what we might call _address abstraction_ since the user is still operating in a paradigm where their multi-signature "account" is conceptualized as a single blockchain address on a single chain rather than a unified, multi-address, multi-chain "account."

Note that none of this is about taking a "cheap shot" at existing user account solutions. What we have today with EOA based wallets is an entirely valid and necessary low-level way to be able to interact with the chain and explicitly authorize signatures from each private key to sign messages or initiate transactions. It is also a highly natural way to organize wallets given the functionalities of ethereum and the tools and standards that were available in the past. However, new tools are coming to ethereum (e.g. EIP-7702 giving EOAs superpowers, ERC-7683 standardizing cross chain intents, and more) which give us the opportunity to redesign the user wallet UX from the ground up. And my argument is this is exactly what we should do!

The single-address account model for user wallets is a fundamental UX bottleneck. It locks users into a primitive, low-level way of interacting with Ethereum--forcing them to think about individual addresses rather than a unified account that intelligently manages multiple addresses and chains under the hood.

If we want to improve Ethereum‚Äôs UX, we must move away from the ‚Äúaddress-by-address‚Äù wallet model and rethink what an account actually means.

Instead of presenting users with a list of EOAs, wallets should present a list of "User Accounts" or "User Identities"‚Äîeach one fully an abstraction over multiple EOAs, smart contract accounts, chains, and privacy protocols.

With this model:

- A user sees a unified account balance (aggregated across a number of addresses and chains etc). User doesn't have to think about address-level concerns.

- When interacting onchain, the wallet intelligently selects which funds in which address(es) on what chain(s) to use (considering privacy, efficiency, bridging etc). User never has to manually worry about bridging or not having gas funds in the right address again.

- User operations automatically bundle necessary steps of a UserOp (cross chain bridging, stealth transfers, deposits/withdraws to privacy protocols, gas payments to relayers) behind the scenes. User only does a single authorization in the wallet even for a complex multi-step operation.

- Users get basic privacy by default from the wallet. Ideally the wallet could expose the privacy trade-offs to users from there (to maintain strong privacy for certain types of UserOps could require sacrificing on speed and/or cost of execution)

To the user, this should feel a lot like a browser wallet today, but under the hood, the wallet is dynamically managing multiple addresses, chains, and privacy mechanisms in an opinionated and optimized way.
